subject: idempotence Re: [junit] Article That Should Help Testing: "Five Habits of Highly Profitable Software Dev
msgSnippet: ... It is not clear to me if this article is aimed at JUnit development, or the business objects that are being tested and developed with JUnit s help. The
messageBody:
robertjmiller_jgs wrote:
> Today, I have a test related article being published on java.net:
> "Five Habits of Highly Profitable Software Developers"
> http://today.java.net/pub/a/today/2006/08/24/five-habits-of-highly-profitable-developers.html

It is not clear to me if this article is aimed at JUnit development, or
the business objects that are being tested and developed with JUnit's help.

The first example, the CustomerAccount is clearly a business object.

Yet the Habit 2 is clearly about Junit methods:
public void testRequestedPasswordIsNotValid
BecauseItMustBeDifferentThanTheUsername()

But my big question is that is the meaning of Habit 5.
It appears to be arguing in favor of implementing idempotent state,
which while useful in some cases, is not generally a characteristic of
business objects.

Am I missing something?

--
Pat Farrell
http://www.pfarrell.com/
